profileText: A Representative from Missouri; born in Mallow, County Cork, Ireland, January 2, 1805; immigrated to the United States in 1817 and settled in Baltimore, Md.; apprenticed to learn the shoemaker's trade; received a limited schooling; became a licensed Methodist preacher before twenty years of age; went West in 1826 and preached in the Illinois conference; entered general merchandise business in Madison, Ill., in 1831; president of the Illinois Board of Public Works 1834-1837; member of the State house of representatives in 1836; unsuccessful Whig candidate for Congress in 1838; register of the land office at Dixon, Ill., 1841-1845; moved to St. Louis, Mo., and engaged in the wholesale grocery business; postmaster of St. Louis 1857-1861; elected as a Democrat to the Thirty-ninth Congress (March 4, 1865-March 3, 1867); unsuccessful candidate in 1866 for reelection to the Fortieth Congress; died in St. Louis, Mo., February 5, 1892; interment in Bellefontaine Cemetery.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Boogher, Sophia Hogan. Recollections of John Hogan by his daughter Mrs. Simon L. Boogher (Sophia Hogan Boogher). St. Louis: [Mound City Press], 1927.
Hogan, John. Basis of representation: Speech of Hon. John Hogan of Missouri, in the House of Representatives, January 30, 1866. [Washington: N.p., 1866].
------. Speech of Hon. John Hogan, of Missouri: Delivered at the Mass Meeting of Irishmen at Grover's Theatre, Washington, on Wednesday evening, August 1, 1866. [Washington, D.C.?: N.p., 1866?]
------. Speech of Hon. John Hogan of Missouri, on trade with British America, tariff, and protection in general: Delivered in the House of Representatives, March 7, 1866. [Washington: N.p., 1866]

researchRecord.name: More than 10 items in the John Caldwell Calhoun papers, 1784-1888. 6 feet (ca. 3,000 items).
researchRecord.description: Index to correspondents in library. Restricted.
